text.text: A Guide to Leytonstone

After a bumpy old ride up the central line, we moseyed in to Leytonstone, also known as 'El Stone'... (that'll catch on just you wait.) It may be a bit shabby round the edges, but in the last two years it's seen some slow and gentle enhancements, gentle-fication if you will. 

We hotfooted up and down the high road meeting all sorts of local characters, all the while sniffing out tall tales and tasty morsels. The verdict? There's heaps of bargain grub to be got, fine wines, tidy cocktails and plenty of community feels.
Best for… warm bakes straight from the oven

tip.text:
The clever folks at Wild Goose Bakery know exactly what they’re doing. They do all this baking and then stack it up in piles in the window. We walked past, a little pool of saliva formed in our mouths, next thing we’re handing over hard earned cash in exchange for pastel de nata, still warm from the oven. Those little tartlets of flaky pastry filled with custard, caramelised and cinnamony touched us in places no-one had in a while.

Pretty much all of the produce is locally sourced, including coffee beans from local roasters Climpson & Sons and sodas from Hackney’s Square Root London. Loose leaf tea is from Scotland - that’s ok right? If you’re foolish enough to be avoiding cinnamon swirls, bake-wells, muffins, flapjacks, brownies, lemon drizzle and the like then we’ll allow you a soup, quiche or sarnie… but we’re watching you.

text.text: The clever folks at Wild Goose Bakery know exactly what they’re doing. They bang out all this baking, then stack it up in piles in the window. We walked past, a little pool of saliva formed in our mouths, next thing we’re nibbling on pastel de nata, still warm from the oven. Those little tartlets of flaky pastry, filled with custard, caramelised and cinnamony, touched us in places no-one had in a while.
Best for… a right bargain Turkish

tip.text:
Stop into this no frills resto for a mighty reasonable lahmacun. Freshly baked flatbread, topped with marinated minced lamb and chopped parsley, onion and tomato. Tear off a chunk, pop the salad in, wrap it up and Bob's your uncle. Best thing we'd eaten in a while.

Decor is basic: there's a couple o' retro posters, colourful Turkish lamps and that's about it. But that's not what you came for, is it? You're here 'cause the falafel is unlike any you've had before, the hummus is creamy as all heck and the pide (Turkish pizza) is pretty nice too. But mainly you're here cause it's BYOB. Get on owner Jay's good side and you might avoid the £5 corkage per bottle of wine. He likes a chat, so you just might. But then again you might not.

text.text: This no frills Turkish is just what we needed after a brisk walk up the high street. We absolutely destroyed their lahmacun - freshly baked flatbread, topped with marinated minced lamb, chopped parsley, onion and tomato. Tear off a chunk, pop the salad in, wrap it up, and Bob's your uncle. You're unlikely to find anything more delicious for three quid.
Best for… a moment of contemplation

tip.text:
The Stone Space is pretty basic as far as galleries go. It's about as 'white cube' as you can get, being made up of one small and very cube-like room, painted white, and nothing else.

Exhibitions range from photography and painting to sculpture and other installations, and usually concentrate on one artist's work. They're keeping it simple; sometimes we pop in when we're in the area - we wouldn't write home about it, but we like it.

text.text: The Stone Space is very basic as far as galleries go. It's a small, cube-shaped room, painted white, that exhibits anything from paintings and photography to large installations. It's a bit hit and miss, but if you're as curious as us, you won't be able to walk past without pressing your face up against the window to see what's good. You shouldn't do that though, or you'll leave a nasty smear on the glass.
Best for… proper East End vibes

tip.text:
Stepping into this baby is like going back in time. One look at their signage tells you they've had the same opening times for a long while and not much has changed. Take the decor for instance, it's super basic with painted red benches, white tiled walls, and a timeless charm.

Your options are, stewed eels, jellied eels, meat pie and mash - and that really is it. Mash and liquor (that thick green parsley sauce) are served out of large vats, giving a proper old school canteen feel. If you've never been to a pie and mash house before this one is sure worth a visit, and full of friendly faces too!

text.text: Stepping into this baby is like going back in time. Your options are, stewed eels, jellied eels, meat pie and mash - and that really is it. The mash and liquor (that thick green parsley sauce) are served out of large vats, giving a proper old school canteen feel. It's like a little piece of East End history, and full of friendly faces too!
Best for… homemade pasta and natural wine

tip.text:
Nothing soothes a broken soul like a good bowl of pasta, and Mora's are bang on. While his wife, Silvia, sorts front of house, Carlo's out back flipping a mighty good pan of papardelle. He's from Sardinia and so are most of the dishes, which use traditional ingredients from the island that us Londoners aren't used to seeing on our plates. Look out for 'bottarga' - salted, cured fish roe - which is shaved over risotto or 'seadas' - deep fried ravioli filled with pecorino and topped with orange marmalade and honey. We crunched our way through a good few of them.

Start with a little tower of aubergine melanzane and then get stuck into their homemade pasta. Or if you're feeling a little more curious, their weekly changing specials focus on a different region of Italy. That means drinks, pasta, and even deserts will be themed. When we were in it was Trentino's turn - which meant strudel got a look in. Pair with local craft beers or something Italian, natural, and organic from the tidy wine list.

text.text: Nothing soothes a broken soul like a good bowl of pasta, and Mora's are bang on. While his wife, Silvia, sorts front of house, Carlo's out back flipping a mighty good pan of papardelle. He's from Sardinia and so are lots of the dishes, ingredients and natural wines. Look out for 'bottarga' - salted, cured fish roe - which is shaved over their homemade pasta. We had ours with artichokes and walnuts - creamy and delightful.
Best for… bringing your own

tip.text:
***Temporarily Closed***

A genuine family-run restaurant, Singburi is all about no-frills, traditional Thai. You really get the feeling these dishes have been passed down through handwritten recipe books. (Maybe because the whole family is present.)

Head chef Sirachai was too shy to let the restaurant be named after him, so Singburi, the region his dad hails from, was the next best choice. He may be shy but he sure ain't lacking in skills. We scoffed spicy, garlicky clams; a hot, fresh papaya salad; and a green curry that put all others to shame. But most importantly, things got a little hot and heavy with a plate of 'moo krob' - crispy pork belly spiced to perfection. We finished with an 'ube' (purple yam) ice cream that soothed our little tongues a treat.

It's not exactly small plates, somewhere in between small and normal size perhaps. Either way you'll want to plough through a few dishes so lucky it's BYOB.

text.text: A genuine family-run restaurant, Singburi is all about traditional Thai. The shy but talented chef, Sirachai, cooked us up some garlicky clams; a spicy, fresh papaya salad; and a green curry that put all others to shame. Then things got a little hot and heavy with a plate of 'moo krob' - crispy pork belly spiced to perfection. BYOB never tasted this good.
Best for… a bottle of quality

tip.text:
The decor is NOT strong with this one, but what they do got is a lot of bottles of good wine, beer, and spirits. In you pop, full of questions, and the mighty friendly staff will do their best to ease your nerves about tannins and the like. And don't worry, there's some affordable bottles of vino to be had, complete with hand written labels explaining tasting notes, food pairings, and tales of the wine producers.

On top of all that, tasting evenings are rife here - ranging from £20 for spirits and cult classic wines to £50 for the bubblier goods. Check the site for their program of events and book yourself a new, cultured you.

text.text: The decor is NOT strong with this one, but what they do got is a lot of good vino, beer, and spirits. In you pop, full of questions, and the mighty friendly staff will do their best to ease your nerves about tannins and the like. There's a few affordable bottles to be had and regular tasting evenings too - with nibbles included and everything!
Best for… Vietnamese finger food

tip.text:
This Vietnamese is very different from the spots you know along Kingsland Road. It may be a little more spenny but it’s a whole lot more spacious, dishes feel considered, and drinks are exciting. We plumped for Fritz-Kola and Saigon special beer - both mighty refreshing.

Mama Pham is the head chef and matriarch. She comes up with new menu items, oversees marinades and just generally kills it while her son Robert sees to front of house. Hit up the reliable and warming pho or make your own summer rolls. Dip your rice paper in the warm water, lay out the sheet, fill it with all things pork, mint and coriander then wrap and roll. Were our rolls anywhere close to profesh looking? No. Did they taste fresh and summery once dipped in chilli sauce? Oh yes.

text.text: Mama Pham is the head chef and matriarch of this spacious Vietnamese. She comes up with new menu items, oversees marinades and just generally kills it while her son Robert sees to front of house. Hit up the reliable and warming pho or make your own summer rolls. We got a little sticky with it but came out on top, tasting fresh mint, coriander and all the rest.
Best for… A right old knees up

tip.text:
The Red Lion is a cracking boozer, filled with a cross section of the community and all different ages. It had us falling in love with pub culture all over again. Chew the ear off a hardened regular and you’ll likely hear tales of The Rolling Stones or Led Zeppelin playing the upstairs ballroom. But screw the past, there’s still plenty goings on these days to keep us curious.

By day freelancers and young mums gather on sofas and in nooks. But by night the pub fills with punters turning up for one of the events. From free cinema and quizzes to garage and northern soul nights, this lot have your monthly calendar sorted. They even have an all day hip hop festival in the summer - where local artists graffiti the walls anew each year. Good British grub, board games, bloody marys, table football, kids' dance classes... it's less of a pub and more the heart of Leytonstone.

text.text: The Red Lion is a cracking boozer, filled with a cross section of the community and all different ages. It had us falling in love with pub culture all over again with tales of The Rolling Stones playing the upstairs ballroom, some of the comfiest sofas about and a mega events line up. From free cinema and quizzes to garage and northern soul nights, this lot have your monthly calendar sorted.
And here's our picks for Leyton...
